section_one_text.value: Google has made hundreds of megabytes of anonymised location data gathered from smartphones available for anyone to download for free.

The stated aim is to help public health officials plan policies in response to the COVID-19 pandemic by allowing them to learn how their citizens’ movements have changed since the start of the pandemic and in response to lockdown restrictions.

The data are broken down by categories of places that people may visit or travel through. These categories include grocery and pharmacies, parks, transit stations, retail & recreation, residential and workplaces.
This map shows the data for just one category, parks. Google's definition of parks includes local and national parks as well as public beaches, marinas, dog parks, plazas, and public gardens.

A red spike on the map indicates an increase in visits and length of stay at this location whereas a blue spike indicates a decrease, relative to a baseline value. Google defines this baseline as the median value, for the corresponding day of the week, during a 5 week period from January 3<sup>rd</sup> to Feb 6<sup>th</sup> in 2020.

The map shows data from February 15<sup>th</sup> 2020 through to May 21<sup>st</sup> 2021, a period of 462 days covering the worst of the pandemic. As you scroll down the page the map will move forward through time.

Each location in the dataset is given a unique Google Place ID. This allows us to use the Google Maps Places API to reference latitude and longitude coordinates for each location so that they can be plotted on the map.

The spikes represent a seven day rolling average of the Google data. This allows us to more clearly see trends emerging between locations over time by smoothing out fluctuations between individual days.

Of the categories, parks show the most dramatic changes over time. This is to be expected since parks will naturally see high fluctuations in their usage depending on the seasons or local public holidays. For instance, I might spend all day in the park if there is nice weather on a bank holiday weekend but I will visit the office five days a week all year regardless of the weather.
The use of parks is also highly dependent on their location. We can see that parks are a lot busier north of the equator during the summer months in the Northern Hemisphere.
As such park usage is not the best category to look at in order to determine how pandemic measures are affecting the movements of the general population.

section_two_text.value: Zooming into England and moving back to February 2020, we are now looking at the data for changes of usage of workplaces over the same period.

The variations are not as dramatic here, although we can see that the usage trends for places of work have been below average since the start of the pandemic and we can see a clear drop in usage coinciding with each new lockdown in England.
Although subtle, the data show that the reduction in usage of workplaces is diminishing as the pandemic continues.

Using the same Google dataset, the London Datastore have concluded that the first England lockdown resulted in an increase of 130% of homeworking at its onset on March 24th 2020, dropping to 125% by the the time some workers were encouraged to return to work on May 10th 2020.

The third England lockdown had slightly less impact on home working. A 122% increase in home working as it began on January 5<sup>th</sup> 2021, dropping to 118% by the time schools reopened on March 8<sup>th</sup> 2020.
If these trends continue we can expect any potential future lockdowns in England to inspire less people to choose to work from home, increasing the risk of transmission in the workplace.
Public health officials in England can use these findings to assess the efficacy of future measures they may plan to control the spread of COVID-19.
The code for this page can be viewed on GitHub.
Data from Google LLC "Google COVID-19 Community Mobility Reports". Accessed: 25th May 2020.
